body: A 6.7 magnitude earthquake hits the Los Angeles area, centered in Northridge. At final count, the quake resulted in 57 people killed, more than 9,000 injured, 125,000 rendered homeless and more than 82,000 buildings damaged in Los Angeles, Ventura, Orange and San Bernardino Counties.
title: 6.7 quake hits L.A.
caption: Cars lie smashed by the collapsed Interstate 5 connector few hours after Northridge earthquake, on Jan. 17, 1994, in Sylmar. (Jonathan Nourok/AFP/Getty Images)

body: The initial rumble is followed by a 5.9 aftershock. Numerous aftershocks followed the initial quake for months, though most were so small they weren't noticeable.
title: 5.9 aftershock follows initial quake
caption: Firemen carry a janitorial worker who was rescued from a collapsed garage at the Northridge Mall after the earthquake, on Jan. 17, 1994, in Northridge. (Denis Poroy/AFP/Getty Images)

body: Mayor Richard Riordan officially declared a state of emergency.
title: Mayor Riordan declares state of emergency

body: California Gov. Pete Wilson officially declared a state of emergency, making it easier for the area to get state resources.
title: Gov. Wilson declares state of emergency

body: Authorities managed to get all active fires under control, helping to prevent further damage.
title: Fires under control
caption: At night, a gas main on fire throws flames into the air after it broke and exploded destroying nearby homes following the Northridge earthquake, on Jan. 17, 1994. (Hal Garb/AFP/Getty Images)

body: President Bill Clinton declared a national disaster for Los Angeles County, helping to direct federal resources to the area following the quake.
title: President Clinton declares national disaster
caption: President Bill Clinton signs in Washington D.C. Jan. 17, 1994 a declaration designating the Los Angeles metropolitan area as a disaster zone eligible for federal aid following the earthquake that rocked the region early in the day. (Jennifer Young/AFP/Getty Images)
readmoresource: The Los Angeles Times: "Earthquake: Disaster Before Dawn: Federal Officials Gear Up Relief Efforts: Response: Clinton confers with state leaders and signs disaster declaration"

body: Several highways were closed going into Tuesday. All I-5 lanes were closed except northbound I-5 to northbound SR-14 truck lanes, all SR-14 Lanes were closed and all I-10 lanes were closed between Centinela and Washington Boulevard and all SR-118 lanes were closed between Tampa Avenue and I-210.  Local streets were used as detours.
title: Multiple highways closed
caption: A bulldozer begins to tear down a section of the Santa Monica Freeway Jan. 19, 1994 that collapsed during the Northridge earthquake. (Tim Clary/AFP/Getty Images)

body: President Bill Clinton arrived two days after the earthquake, touring the damage from the disaster.
title: President Clinton arrives
caption: President Bill Clinton (C) waves to residents Jan. 19, 1994 during a tour of earthquake stricken areas near Los Angeles. Clinton toured damaged roadways and viewed urban damage. (Paul J. Richards/AFP/Getty Images)

title: Los Angeles Mayor Richard Riordan declares curfew
caption: Firemen cross a street as a broken 16-inch gas main burns in the background, Jan. 17, 1994, after an earthquake struck the San Fernando Valley area.(Hal Garb/AFP/Getty Images)

title: Vice President Gore visits Cal State Northridge
caption: Former Vice President Al Gore addresses a conference commemorating the 10th anniversary of the Center for American Progress in the Astor Ballroom of the St. Regis Hotel. October 24, 2013 in Washington, DC. (Chip Somodevilla/Getty Images)

body: A 5.3 aftershock caused new damage months after the initial quake.
title: 5.3 aftershock hits

body: The Interstate 10 freeway reopened, 74 days ahead of schedule.
title: I-10 freeway reopens

body: The Golden State Freeway at Gavin Canyon reopened following the Northridge earthquake.
title: I-5 freeway fully reopens
Last ramps at I-5/SR-14 interchange reopen
caption: Aerial view of wrecked cars litter the connector ramp from Interstate 5 to Highway 14 following the Northridge earthquake, on Jan. 17, 1994. During the earthquake damage was widespread, sections of major freeways collapsed, parking structures and office buildings collapsed and numerous apartment buildings suffered irreparable damage. (Carlos Chiebeck/AFP/Getty Images)

body: President Clinton visited Cal State Northridge one year after the Northridge earthquake.
title: President Clinton visits Cal State Northridge
caption: President Bill Clinton waves to the crowd on Jan. 17, 1995 as he stands in front of the photograph of a parking structure that was damaged at California State University, Northridge. The president ordered a team of government experts who dealt with the Northridge quake to go to Japan to see what assistance could be offered there. (Hal Garb/AFP/Getty Images)

body: The Northridge Fashion Center reopened August 2, 1995 after 18 months of repairs following the quake. The Center first opened its doors to the public in 1971.
title: Northridge Fashion Center reopens
caption: A Macy's department store now stands at Northridge Fashion Center, where Bullocks Department Store was severely damaged 20 years ago in the Northridge Earthquake on Jan. 17, 1994. (Maya Sugarman/KPCC)
